israel.total_estimate_1995_2025: Under $1 billion, mostly post-2020 and indirect.

article.title: Saudi Arabia’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Saudi Arabia’s investments in the US over the past 30 years reflect its role as a major global investor, driven by oil wealth and the Public Investment Fund (PIF). By 1990, Saudi Arabia held $100–$200 billion in US assets, including a $2 billion stake in Texaco’s refining operations. Post-1995, investments diversified into tech (e.g., $3.5 billion in Uber, 2016) and infrastructure ($20 billion with Blackstone, 2017). In May 2025, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman pledged $600 billion during Trump’s visit, including $142 billion for defense and $20 billion for AI via DataVolt. In Israel, investments were negligible until the 2020 Abraham Accords, with tacit defense cooperation emerging (e.g., $800 million in Israeli defense exports to Arab states). Public sentiment in Saudi Arabia opposes Israel ties (96% prioritize Palestine, 2023 poll), limiting overt investments. US investments face scrutiny over deliverability due to low oil prices, with only $283 billion of the 2025 pledge detailed.

article.title: UAE’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: The UAE has emerged as a major investor in the US, leveraging sovereign wealth funds like ADIA and Mubadala. By 1990, UAE’s foreign investments were estimated at $80–$100 billion, with significant US holdings. Key deals include ADIA’s $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup (2007) and Mubadala’s $1.3 billion in SoftBank’s Vision Fund (2018). In March 2025, following a meeting with Trump, the UAE committed to a 10-year $1.4 trillion investment framework focusing on artificial intelligence, energy infrastructure, and technology sectors. In Israel, investments started post-2020 Abraham Accords, with a $1 billion stake in the Tamar gas field and $605 million in tech ventures. Public sentiment supports diversification but faces regional criticism over Israel ties (67% negative views on Gaza stance, 2023). The long-term nature of the 2025 investment framework reflects UAE's strategic commitment to US economic partnership.

article.title: Qatar’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Qatar’s investments in the US, driven by the Qatar Investment Authority, have grown significantly since the 2000s, focusing on real estate, finance, and aviation. A $35 billion pledge in 2015 targeted US infrastructure, followed by a $96 billion Qatar Airways Boeing deal (2023–2024). In May 2025, Emir Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani announced a $1.2 trillion ‘economic exchange,’ including $10 billion for Al Udeid Air Base and a $400 million Air Force One gift, raising ethical concerns. Only $243.5 billion of the 2025 pledge is detailed, casting doubt on deliverability. In Israel, Qatar has no significant investments due to its pro-Palestinian stance and lack of formal ties, though post-2020, it coordinates Gaza aid with Israel’s approval. Public sentiment in Qatar opposes Israel ties, prioritizing Palestine, while US investments align with strengthening military and economic partnerships.

united_states.overview: Kuwait’s Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA) has been a major investor in the US since the 1980s, focusing on finance, real estate, and energy.

key_investments.description: KIA acquired Santa Fe International, a US oil services company.

KIA invested in US-based tech firms via venture capital funds.

united_states.total_estimate_1995_2025: Approximately $200–$300 billion, based on KIA’s global portfolio estimates.

israel.overview: No direct investments due to Kuwait’s non-recognition of Israel and strong pro-Palestinian stance.

article.title: Kuwait’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Kuwait’s investments in the US, managed by the Kuwait Investment Authority (KIA), have been significant since the 1980s, with an estimated $80–$100 billion in US assets by 1990. Notable deals include the $2.5 billion acquisition of Santa Fe International (1981) and a $5 billion stake in British Petroleum (1988), partially redirected to US markets. Post-1995, KIA invested in US tech and real estate, including a $1 billion tech fund in 2019. Kuwait’s conservative investment strategy focuses on stable returns, aligning with its oil wealth management. In Israel, Kuwait has no investments due to its firm non-recognition policy and support for Palestine, reinforced by public sentiment. Data on recent US investments is limited, as KIA discloses few specifics, but its US portfolio remains substantial.

article.title: Bahrain’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Bahrain’s investments in the US, managed by Mumtalakat, are modest due to its smaller economy. Key deals include $500 million in real estate and finance (2008) and $600 million in infrastructure (2017). Bahrain’s focus is on stable US assets to diversify from oil. In Israel, investments emerged post-2020 Abraham Accords, with $50 million in tech startups, reflecting new trade ties. Public opposition, especially from Bahrain’s Shia majority, limits Israel investments due to pro-Palestinian sentiment. Data on Bahrain’s US investments is sparse, as Mumtalakat discloses limited details, but its US portfolio supports economic diversification. Bahrain’s smaller scale compared to Saudi Arabia or UAE constrains its investment capacity.

article.title: Egypt’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Egypt’s investments in the US are minimal, constrained by economic challenges and reliance on US aid ($1.3 billion annually). Private investors contributed $100 million to US real estate in 2016, but large-scale investments are rare. In Israel, despite the 1979 peace treaty, no significant investments exist due to strong public opposition (5% support normalization, Arab Barometer 2022) and Egypt’s focus on domestic priorities. Flight capital from Egyptians working in Gulf states often flows to the US, but data is limited. Egypt’s economic constraints and pro-Palestinian stance limit its role as an investor in both countries.

article.title: Jordan’s Investments in the US and Israel, 1995–2025
article.content: Jordan’s investments in the US are limited due to its small economy and reliance on US aid ($1 billion annually). Private investors, including expatriates in the Gulf, invested $50 million in US tech startups in 2018. In Israel, despite the 1994 peace treaty, investments are negligible due to public opposition (5% support normalization, Arab Barometer 2022) and economic constraints. Jordan’s focus remains on domestic development and Palestinian issues, limiting its role as an investor in both countries. Data on US investments is scarce, reflecting Jordan’s minor financial footprint.

notes.overview: Arab investments in the US are dominated by Gulf states (Saudi Arabia, UAE, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain), driven by sovereign wealth funds and oil wealth. Total investments from 1995–2025 are estimated at over $3 trillion, with Saudi Arabia, UAE, and Qatar accounting for the majority. Investments in Israel are limited, mostly post-2020 Abraham Accords, totaling under $3 billion, primarily from UAE and Bahrain. Other Arab countries (e.g., Morocco, Sudan, Oman) have negligible investments in Israel and minimal US investments due to economic or political constraints.
challenges: Data on Arab investments is often incomplete, as sovereign wealth funds disclose limited details.
Low oil prices since 2014 have strained Gulf budgets, raising doubts about fulfilling recent pledges (e.g., $1.4 trillion UAE, $1.2 trillion Qatar).
Public opposition in Arab countries limits Israel investments, with normalization support below 20% in most states (Arab Barometer, 2021–2022).
notes.ethical_concerns: Trump family business ties (e.g., World Liberty Financial in UAE, real estate in Saudi Arabia) raise conflict-of-interest concerns in 2025 pledges.
